message_1: What is the standard enthalpy of combustion of propane, and how does it compare to the enthalpy of combustion of butane at the same temperature and pressure? Provide a mathematical explanation for your answer, including all relevant chemical equations and data tables.
message_2:
The standard enthalpy of combustion is the amount of heat released when one mole of a substance is completely burned in oxygen under standard conditions (25°C and 1 atm pressure). In this case, we will compare the standard enthalpy of combustion of propane (C3H8) and butane (C4H10).

The balanced chemical equations for the combustion of propane and butane are:

Propane:
C3H8(g) + 5O2(g) → 3CO2(g) + 4H2O(l)

Butane:
C4H10(g) + 6.5O2(g) → 4CO2(g) + 5H2O(l)

To determine the standard enthalpy of combustion for each reaction, we can use the standard enthalpies of formation (∆Hf°) for each compound involved. The standard enthalpies of formation are as follows (in kJ/mol):

C3H8(g): -103.85
C4H10(g): -126.3
O2(g): 0
CO2(g): -393.5
H2O(l): -285.8

Using Hess's Law, the standard enthalpy of combustion (∆Hc°) can be calculated as the sum of the standard enthalpies of formation of the products minus the sum of the standard enthalpies of formation of the reactants:

For propane:
∆Hc° = [3(-393.5) + 4(-285.8)] - [(-103.85) + 5(0)]
∆Hc° = (-1180.5 - 1143.2) - (-103.85)
∆Hc° = -2323.7 + 103.85
∆Hc° = -2219.85 kJ/mol

For butane:
∆Hc° = [4(-393.5) + 5(-285.8)] - [(-126.3) + 6.5(0)]
∆Hc° = (-1574 - 1429) - (-126.3)
∆Hc° = -3003 + 126.3
∆Hc° = -2876.7 kJ/mol

Now we can compare the standard enthalpy of combustion of propane and butane. The standard enthalpy of combustion of propane is -2219.85 kJ/mol, while the standard enthalpy of combustion of butane is -2876.7 kJ/mol. This means that butane releases more energy per mole when burned compared to propane under the same temperature and pressure.
